Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "CurrentUICulture/CurrentCulture not working in Razor view rendering with asynchronuous controller actions" (#3117) at aspnet/Home
Opened issue "CurrentUICulture/CurrentCulture not working in Razor view rendering with asynchronuous methods" (#3117) at aspnet/Home
Opened issue "[Question] Diagnostics - UseExceptionHandler culture in url" (#3116) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

I've written a middleware that handles localization via url if the culture is not present in the url segment. So `home/about` will be redirected to e.g `sv/home/about`. 

When adding the `ExceptionHandleMiddleware` I've a few options and I choose `UseExceptionHandler("/error/500")`.  In the method the `HttpContext.Features.Get<IExceptionHandlerPathFeature>` is always `null`, most likely to the redirect my middleware performs due to the lack of culture. How to I best solve this issue?

1. Re-write my middleware to **not** delete the related items/features/.... Maybe doing this copy is expensive and that is something I would like to avoid.
2. Add an overload to the `UseExceptionHandler` which allows me to construct the path at runtime. Perhaps `Func<HttpContext, string>` then I can resolve `IRequestCultureFeature` from context and extract the culture and create the correct path. This would be added to the options object


Thanks

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "After the update to 2.1-preview2 new DocumentClient() fails only on Azure, killing the whole application" (#3115) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Posting this here because the DocumentClient library doesn't seem to have a proper separate repo. I've also filed it here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-documentdb-dotnet/issues/495, but it seems pretty dead to me.

I am having a very strange issue here. This all started happening after the update to preview2 of .NET Core 2.1.

The project works totally fine on my local machine, but fails after a few clicks when hosted on Azure. I have isolated the issue to a single line, which is 
`new DocumentClient(settings.Endpoint, settings.ReadKey);`
The settings are fine, the same issue appears if I hardcode the strings. 

This line is called in a constructor for a service that's registered in `Startup.cs`.

The strange thing is that I don't get any exceptions, I don't get any DI errors, after a few minutes it just says that the process was terminated and the whole application stops working. It also happens on exactly the 2nd time I'm calling the controller into which I'm injecting the service.

Any pointers or hints?

I'm using the latest (1.9.1.) version of the `Microsoft.Azure.DocumentDB.Core` assembly and the `dotnet --version` output is `2.1.300-preview2-008530`, both on local and on Azure.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Need a better error message when kestrel cannot get the requested port" (#3114) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This is what I see when Kestrel cannot get the port I asked for. This is on .NET Core 2.1 RC1 (with a 2.0 app).

pi@raspberrypi:~/dotnet-docker/samples/aspnetapp/aspnetapp $ export ASPNETCORE_URLS=http://+:80
pi@raspberrypi:~/dotnet-docker/samples/aspnetapp/aspnetapp $ dotnet run
crit: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel[0]
      Unable to start Kestrel.
Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Transport.Libuv.Internal.Networking.UvException: Error -13 EACCES permission denied
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Transport.Libuv.Internal.Networking.LibuvFunctions.ThrowError(Int32 statusCode)
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Transport.Libuv.Internal.Networking.LibuvFunctions.ThrowIfErrored(Int32 statusCode)
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Transport.Libuv.Internal.Networking.LibuvFunctions.tcp_bind(UvTcpHandle handle, SockAddr

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Update ISSUE_TEMPLATE with clearer instructions" (#3113) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: I went to Antiforgery repo, it said raise an issue here. I read this template and it told me to create it in a specific repository. Um, what?  This should hopefully make it clearer.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Antiforgery : API misleading" (#3112) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
`IAntiforgery` - `Task<bool> IsRequestValidAsync(HttpContext httpContext);`

If you setup Antiforgery with header name `Foo` and on the client set this value and try a POST/PUT, all is well.

On the client then add the header again.

What you end up with is a header with that key with two values.

Agreed, not what you should do but lets look over that.

Send a request and you get:
```
System.InvalidOperationException: The antiforgery token could not be decrypted. ---> System.FormatException: The input is not a valid Base-64 string as it contains a non-base 64 character, more than two padding characters, or an illegal character among the padding characters.
```

This is because https://github.com/aspnet/Antiforgery/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Antiforgery/Internal/DefaultAntiforgeryTokenStore.cs#L41 pulls out the header as `StringValues` which will have a 2 values. Then passes this to the constructor of `AntiforgeryTokenSet` whose first argument is a string. Converting a `StringValues` to `string` implicitly with more than one value will pull out the first value.  In our case the incorrect value.

Further down the stack where it takes this value and calls `IAntiforgeryTokenSerializer.Deserialize` it blows up with the exception not return an expected false.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "switch tests to 'jest' (#2193)" (#2203) at aspnet/SignalR
Closed issue "Switch unit testing infrastructure to Jest" (#2196) at aspnet/SignalR
Events.RelatedBody:
https://facebook.github.io/jest/

Pros:
* It has better support for async
* It runs test files in parallel
* It has a better TypeScript plugin
* It has built-in support for mocking timers

Cons:
* It doesn't replace Jasmine entirely, we still need that for the browser tests
* It's another dependency (but only for internal testing use)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Info-level logging about page execution is confusing" (#7602) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody:
Messages mix page and handler mentions with action mentions when logging about the same request e.g.
```
Route matched with {page = "/Account/Register", area = "Identity", action = "", controller = ""}. Executing action /Account/Register
...
Executed action /Account/Register in 2275.7977ms
```
versus (in between the two messages above)
```
Executing handler method OnPostAsync with arguments () - ModelState is Valid
```

Should stick with consistent terms, preferably without expanding the meaning of "action". In addition, the `Executing handler method` message should fully qualify the method name, as we do in similar (true) action messages e.g.
```
Executing action method netcoreIndividualAuth2_1Preview2.Controllers.HomeController.Index (netcoreIndividualAuth2_1Preview2) - Validation state: Valid
```

----
Found while running through aspnet/Release#263

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Modify info level logging for pages" (#7733) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody: Addresses #7602

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Map asp.net core 2.0 Identity to existing DB schema" (#1768) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody:
I have built a small web application with asp.net core 2.0 MVC. In this web application, I did not implement any authentication methods so far.

Right now I have an MSSQL database running in the background and I can add/view/edit/delete users from the database. I adapted the following tutorial: https://www.c-sharpcorner.com/article/crud-operation-with-asp-net-core-mvc-web-app-using-ado-net/ and followed it pretty closely. However I also added some functionality like localization and stuff, and everything is running pretty smoothly.

My next goal is to enable authentication and authorization. The authentication part shall be straightforward. The goal is that the application will be running as an intranet solution. This means the authentication method just shall check if the Windows User is existing in the previously mentioned database. I don't want to create a separate login. However, it might be that there is a Windows user in the active directory, which is not part of the database. This User should just be able to see a default error page.

I made quite a huge research and I also tried a lot of different stuff, however, I do absolutely not find any "database first" tutorial for this part or any other documentation which explains what to do.

I actually "just" want to teach the asp.net core 2.0 identity framework that it shall look into my user-table and check if the current windows user is existent and if not to forward him to the error page. A second step would be to load all the roles which this user is assigned to from the mapping table.

Any kind of help would be highly appreciated.

Opened pull request "[WIP] Throw ConnectionAbortedException when uv_write fails with ECANCELED" (#2547) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody: I'll add tests for this later.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "When the server aborts a connection any readers should get an OperationCanceled exception instead of an IOException" (#2546) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody: Sometimes when the connection is aborted by the server with the libuv transport, uv_write will fail with ECANCELED which will cause any attempt to read from the connection to throw an IOException instead of an OperationCanceledException like you would see from the Socket transport or even the libuv transport if the connection wasn't aborted mid-write.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Autogenerate parts of TransportConnection" (#2545) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody: A lot of the feature collection implementation for TransportConnection can be auto generated like it is for HttpProtocol. We should do this, since writing the same code manually is prone to copy-and-paste bugs.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Make some new Kestrel types internal" (#2544) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Events.RelatedBody: There were some new public types added to Kestrel between 2.0 and 2.1 that don’t need to be exposed. We should make them internal to alleviate back compat concerns going forward.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Make new types that shouldn't be exposed internal" (#2543) at aspnet/KestrelHttpServer
Opened issue "Make Razor's Workspace lookup logic more flexible to other variations of the C# content type." (#2335) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
We should change [this](https://github.com/aspnet/Razor/blob/b538f22ad58da4b4cd79b9c1c5e7f353f11fc52c/src/Microsoft.VisualStudio.LanguageServices.Razor/DefaultVisualStudioWorkspaceAccessor.cs#L83) to look for the `"Roslyn"` content type instead of the `"CSharp"` content type. Given that this code is being called we're already guaranteed to be in an ASP.NET Core Razor scenario which only supports C#.

This unblocks liveshare scenarios were content types get changed to have remote prefixes/suffixes.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Upgrade to netcoreapp22" (#2334) at aspnet/Razor
Opened pull request "Bump Roslyn dependency to 2.8.0" (#2333) at aspnet/Razor
Opened issue "Update Microsoft.CodeAnalysis packages to 2.8.0" (#2332) at aspnet/Razor
Opened pull request "Add more UI for document generation" (#2331) at aspnet/Razor
Merged pull request "Allow build server to run on net46" (#2327) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
Fixes #2325 

For security reasons, we were not starting the build server whenever `PipeOptions.CurrentlyUserOnly` isn't available. But when running on desktop .NET Framework aka VS on Windows, that flag will never be available causing the build server to not start in VS builds. The fix is to use the same workaround used by Roslyn to verify pipe ownership without relying on the PipeOptions flag.

I'm now working on manually verifying if this fix works in VS.

@rynowak @mkArtakMSFT

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ASP.NET Core WebHooks moved out of ASP.NET Core 2.1" (#299) at aspnet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We are moving ASP.NET Core WebHooks out of the ASP.NET Core 2.1 to give more time to validate the design and implementation. We will continue to ship previews ASP.NET Core WebHooks packages, but they not ship as stable packages as part of the ASP.NET Core 2.1 release.

### Why?

[ASP.NET Core WebHooks](https://github.com/aspnet/webhooks) is only a partial port of [ASP.NET WebHooks](https://github.com/aspnet/aspnetwebhooks) and hasn't received sufficient attention during the ASP.NET Core 2.1 release for us to feel comfortable shipping it at this time.
